content:
This clash isn't fair for Reverse mode currently.

All test cases can be solved with simply "string.size % 9" as the answer, there is no test case that forces clashers to repeatedly do it until a single digit is reached. Without such a test case, it's not fair to expect clashers to reverse engineer the solution from incomplete information.

It sucks to get 100% on tests then only 75% on Validators, and it's completely unfair when it happens on Reverse. You should add a test case that has a solution that is not the same as simply "string.size % 9".

Currently it's just Validator 1 that causes an issue, since you expect "9" as the answer, and not "0".

âœ… Approved the contribution.
Comment: This is a quick, fun puzzle that takes two relatively simple concepts and rolls them into a single puzzle. I think the test cases are well set up, i.e. the first length that is above 9 is ten, and that's supposed to give you a 1, which is fairly easy to see. Love the puzzle!

I have removed my rejection, but I cannot approve cause I'm biased by now.

Sorry,

âœ… Approved the contribution.
Comment: I quite enjoyed this clash and it fits very well with the reverse game mode. It is a cool idea for two very simple ideas (length of string and digit sum) to be combined into one clash. Nice job!

I wouldn't be able to figure this out from the examples. Looking at your code, it looks like you are calculating the digital root of the length of the string, but I can't imagine how I would guess that. This would be doable if the input was numbers instead of strings, and there were some numbers of 3+ digits, since the pattern can't be discerned without those. There are too many possibilities for what would happen after the length is more than 20.

Thank you for taking the time to provide detailed feedback on my contribution. I truly appreciate the effort you've put into reviewing it.

I've carefully considered your concerns and have made adjustments accordingly. Specifically, I've restructured the test cases to ensure a more balanced distribution in terms of length, as well as aligned the validators with their respective tests.

I understand the importance of ensuring that the solution remains challenging yet fair for players, especially during the reverse phase. I believe these changes address the issues you've raised and provide a clearer pattern for players to follow.

I hope that with these modifications, the clash will now meet the standards expected. However, if there are still any lingering doubts or further improvements needed, I will simply move into another problem.

Once again, thank you for your valuable feedback and considerations. I'm committed to delivering the best possible contributions to the platform.
It's impossible for me to understand what to do without looking at the code. Either I'm not very clever, or this CoC is too difficult.

This is a good clash if you already knew that the output had to do something with the length of the string, but based on the varied selection of words and the plenty of reverse CoCs where the output is something like the number of lowercase letters or vowels, it's quite hard to figure out and think differently. Maybe just the length would be enough to make it a decent reverse clash, I'm not sure about that one though ðŸ¤·

âœ… Approved the contribution.
Comment: it looks to be a good challenge!
this is super hard as the solution has no connection with the given strings itself

Stub generator
* Please change 800000 to a reasonable number.

* Please add a write statement (e.g. "write answer").

Thanks.

hey, 
Thanks for the feedback, 
Do you know how to show more tests like the first test?
Not that hard, it is related because it start by the size of the string, and then the question should be asked is why the solution is always 1 digit.
its just tricky ^^'

I withdrew my rejection, since the threat of imminent approval is removed and you heard the message. I cannot approve, since I already know the objective and cannot honestly judge it as a fresh reverse player anymore.

I'd suggest to add a 5th and 6th pair of test/validators with >18 chars (or even one with >18 and one with >27). >18 chars is annoying enough to count so that players will try to solve it with the first four cases. However the fifth and sixth case will then help to confirm the pattern once a player found it. Only four cases leaves room for a lot of uncertainty regarding the pattern, since numbers can mean SO MUCH.
...but the case of 9 is only visible in a validator, while the rest can be solved with %9. So it is not possible for reverse players who do not see that validator.

Huh while checking this clash earlier I thought that the correct solution was %9. Apparently not - and only not for validator 1, which as you point out is very bad. Then what is actually the idea? %9 but when 0 then 9?

It's finding the 'digital root' of the string length, which is basically (length % 9 - 1) % 9 + 1, and behaves just as you say. It is just length % 9 except 0 is printed as 9.

The test cases need urgent attention for this to be made fair. Let's see if the author responds soon, otherwise I might modify it to add at least one test case that is a multiple of 9 (and hence has a digital root of 9 and a modulus of 0 relative to 9).

Did any of you modify the cases? Just a reminder to leave a comment if you do.

Also, for the record, I'd rather let a bad clash die than try to salvage it.

I don't think I did, but someone has, since there are now a lot of tests/validators with 9 as the answer. Too many, I would say.

If there were a way to let bad clashes die without giving clashers issues in the meantime I'd be in agreement, but I can't stand reverse clashes with poorly defined tests.
Yes, somebody modified the cases during the week, but I don't know who.
You can play later test cases manually in the IDE, I definitely have to do this on a lot of existing clashes and I think that's alright here.

No the point is that for a reverse player, all test cases give 100% score with just the code len(string)%9, but then hidden in a validator is the fact that len of 9 should return 9 instead of 0. So, this clash is impossible to correctly solve for reverse players.

PLEASE ADD MORE CASES WITH LONGER STRINGS, and bring your test and validator in balance. See @stepback's comment. If indeed the solution is %9 but if zero then +9, then the edges are not at all tested (include a 9, an 18, a 27, a +27 case).
@ðŸ˜³: Your profile picture fits perfect with giving comments like 'this is super hard'.
There isn't any way. The Reverse mode layout is only shown during an actual clash.
Got it, thank you.
